Award.AwardTitle: The Role of Academic Achievement and Social Inclusion in Broadening STEM Participation: Intended and Actual Attainment at the Intersection of Gender and Race/Ethnicity

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This study makes a major contribution to the literature on disparities in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) education by providing new information about the STEM trajectories of boys and girls from various racial/ethnic subgroups from middle school through the end of college. Using five comprehensive, large-scale and longitudinal datasets, researchers from the University of Texas at Austin will examine differences between subgroups in intended as well as actual STEM attainment and investigate how patterns of academic achievement and social inclusion contribute to those differences. Three of the five datasets are nationally representative samples while the other two were collected in Texas and include large sample populations of Hispanic students. Separately the five datasets provide the opportunity to examine certain unique measures of academic achievement and social inclusion; collectively they provide the chance to investigate STEM trajectories at the intersection of race/ethnicity and gender from the 6th grade to the end of college. Special attention will be paid to the experiences of minority girls/women and minority boys/men to gain a more comprehensive and comparative picture of contemporary patterns of inequality.

The analysis focuses on two research aims: 1) to examine how academic achievement and social inclusion contribute to differences in intended STEM attainment during middle and high school by gender and racial/ethnic subgroup; and 2) to examine how academic achievement and social inclusion contribute to differences in actual STEM attainment during college by gender and racial/ethnic subgroup. Statistical analyses include models using logistic and multinomial logistic regression and multi-level models to examine school or classroom level effects. Intended STEM attainment is measured using the answers to various survey questions about desired occupation and comparing the relative preferences with non-STEM occupations. Academic achievement is measured using grades, test scores and course-taking. Social inclusion is measured using answers to questions about perceived peer and teacher support and perceived equitable treatment. The framework of the study is grounded in theories of intersectionality that focus on the intersection of gender and race/ethnicity and the multiple jeopardy that may apply when one is a member of two different groups with relatively lower status. This analysis uses large-scale data to explicitly address the experiences of different groups and to uncover patterns that may affirm this jeopardy or identify instances of resiliency when students succeed in educational environments.

The ultimate goal of the project is to broaden STEM participation by contributing new knowledge about the factors that promote or impede the retention and attainment of women and minority youth in STEM fields. Findings will be presented at academic and policy-related conferences, published in top-tier peer-reviewed journals in education and sociology, and distributed through press releases to local and national media outlets to reach a broad public audience. The research team will also use their extant relationships with national teacher professional development programs to communicate research findings to key audiences of primary and secondary teachers across the country. Additionally, the project is working to broaden participation through the recruitment and training of women and minority doctoral students in the fields of STEM education and sociology. The diverse perspectives of these students, coupled with the rigorous analytical training they will receive, are critical for preparing future generations of academic researchers to study STEM equality.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The continued under-representation of women and individuals from minoritized backgrounds in science, technological, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields is a pressing societal concern. This NSF funded project makes an important new contribution to research on inequality in STEM fields through a simultaneous focus on disparities by gender and race/ethnicity in students’ STEM trajectories from middle school through college, and a consideration of both the academic and social dimensions of inequality. To do so, the research team utilized data from several different large-scale longitudinal datasets collected by the National Center of Education Statistics (NCES) for the U.S. Department of Education, as well as data collected in Texas that provided the opportunity to specifically explore the experiences of Hispanic youth, a relatively under-studied population in the STEM literature. Each of these data sources offers unique affordances to investigate gender and racial/ethnic inequality in STEM fields.

Overall, the project findings highlight how gender and racial inequality in STEM fields are socially constructed, with institutional and contextual factors shaping and constraining opportunities, despite the strong capabilities of girls and students of color. The project has shown how this occurs in postsecondary institutions, high schools, and middle schools. For example, key findings reveal that the racial/ethnic composition of middle schools has implications for who has the opportunity to enroll in the gate-keeping course of 8th grade algebra, as White students maintain an advantage in enrollment in racially integrated schools largely due to their previous advantages in grades and test scores, while Black youth in predominantly Hispanic schools remain under-represented despite comparable academic performance to their peers. Results from another study revealed that compared to teachers in other school types, teachers in predominantly Black middle schools reported spending significantly less class time on algebra and more advanced math content in 8th grade algebra classes.

Findings from this project also demonstrate the continued salience of stereotype and bias and their role in creating an exclusionary STEM environment from middle school through college. For example, one study revealed that exposure to a higher percentage of 8th grade male peers in the classroom who endorsed explicit stereotypes about males’ greater math ability negatively predicted girls’ later intentions to pursue a computer science or engineering major. Yet there is also evidence that endorsing counter-stereotypes can help young people see themselves in STEM fields. Specifically, one study revealed that Black and Hispanic adolescent girls were actually more likely than their male peers to view scientists as well-rounded individuals with many interests, and that holding such views was associated with higher intentions of pursuing a computer science or engineering major. Findings from another study revealed that Black female high school students were more likely than their White peers to believe that girls were in fact better at math than boys; and such beliefs were predictive of actual decisions to enter STEM majors in college several years later. Results of studies of postsecondary STEM pathways further revealed that while women have comparable rates of persistence as men, Black and Hispanic students have lower persistence rates than their White peers, a pattern that cannot be explained by social or academic background and which is consistent with other research on microaggressions and stereotype threat within STEM postsecondary spaces.

 

Overall, project findings highlight the systemic nature of gender and racial inequality in STEM fields, with institutional norms and practices functioning in conjunction with stereotypes and bias to produce continued disparities. Correspondingly, these findings contradict widespread narratives of inequality as the result of individual failures or choices on the part of female students and students of color.  As such, it is critically important to acknowledge that progress towards STEM equity requires structural and organizational change.
